message.content: This question requires basic knowledge of heat transfer. When an object used for cooking food, such as a stove or an oven, is close to a soda can, the heat from the cooking object can be transferred to the soda can, causing it to become hot. Option (A) is incorrect because mixing soda does not involve heat. Option (C) is incorrect because cooling food does not involve transferring heat to the soda can. Option (D) is incorrect because pouring soda does not involve heat transfer.

This question requires basic knowledge about heat transfer. When an object used for cooking food, like a stove or hotplate, is close to a soda can, the heat from the cooking object can be transferred to the can through conduction. This can cause the can to become hot. Option (A) is incorrect because mixing soda does not involve heat transfer. Option (C) is incorrect because cooling food involves removing heat, not adding it. Option (D) is incorrect because pouring soda does not involve heat transfer.

This question requires basic knowledge about the transfer of heat. When an object used for cooking food (such as a stove or oven) is nearby, it produces heat. This heat can be transferred to the soda can through conduction, resulting in the can becoming hot. Options (A), (C), and (D) are not related to the transfer of heat and are therefore incorrect.
